members.member:
Returns whether a follow relationship from the receiver to the requester exists.
Unique identifier of the receiving user. Unique identifier of the requesting user.
TODO THOMAS I suspect that this exists to battle the double-follow-request race conditions. These should never be a problem as long as the follow request processsing pipeline is transactional. --> postgresql

member.summary: Handles our hash distribution.

member.summary: Constructor for dependency injection.

member.name: M:Swabbr.Core.Services.HashDistributionService.GetForMinute(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Swabbr.Core.Entities.SwabbrUserMinified},System.DateTimeOffset,System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary: Uses hash distribution to get all users which trigger in a given moment.

member.name: M:Swabbr.Core.Services.HashDistributionService.GetHashMinute(Swabbr.Core.Entities.SwabbrUserMinified,System.DateTime,System.Int32)
member.summary: Hashes a single into a corresponding minute of the day, represented as value.
member.remarks:
This algorithm computes a Murmur3 hash of a composed string value which contains: - The user id - The day - The request index, ranging between 1 and the vlog request limit for that user The computed hash is then converted to a uint32. The resulting minute is computed by taking the plus the uint32 modulo .
This ignores the value.
member.param: Index of the request on the day
member.returns: The minute in the day based on the inputs
